result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Richard Daniel Ohara

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt: 11:55 AM Cases 22CF108, 21CF314, 21CT81, 21TR891, and 21TR892 called together.  Attorney Alysja Otten in court, appearing by video conferencing.  James Jay Rennicke appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Atty Otten by video.  Cases not scheduled, but def has failed to turn himself in as ordered.  Court orders warrant, body only, in all files, only judge may quash.  Atty Otten makes record- only on 21CT81 and 21CF314 as of now and notes def did not receive notice of this hearing.  Court defaults def in the TR files and assesses amounts on citations.  DA to file paperwork for arrest warrants in the criminal files.

10:35 AM Cases 21CF314, 21CT81, 21TR891, 21TR892, 22CF108 called together.  Defendant, Richard Daniel Ohara, appeared with Attorney Alysja Otten.  Attorney James Jay Rennicke appeared for the State.  Richard Daniel Ohara appeared by video means, but is not successfully connecting to the video conference (Court cannot see or hear him).  Court makes record.  Case 21CF314 on for motion hearing on def's motion.  Case 22CF108 iss set for initial appearance.  Defendant connects to audio and video 10:38 AM.  Case 21CF314 proceeds to motion hearing.  State calls first witness, Deputy Bailey Mangen, who is sworn in and testifies.  Witness identifies the defendant.  Venue is made.  State rests.  Atty Otten crosses.  State objects- calls for legal conclusion; atty Otten responds; DA responds; overruled.  Atty Rennicke redirects.  Recross by Atty Otten.  Court asks for clarification.  Recross continues.  Witness steps down.  State makes statement, second witness not needed as outstanding warrant is not a contested issue.  State argues against motion to suppress.  Atty Otten argues for motion to suppress.  DA makes rebuttal.  Court takes judicial notice of the location of the incident.  Court denies the suppression motion.  Court approves Zoom for next status conference.  DA raises issue of on-camera gesture; discussion.  Court calls recess.  11:25 AM, off the record to review footage.  Back on the record 11:37 AM, same appearances as previously noted.  Court has reviewed the video, addresses the defendant, confirms gesture, finds def in contempt, will allow def to allecute.  Def allecutes, apologizes.  Court issues warrant, def may turn himself in or be arrested; Court sanctions def to 10 days in jail.  Court orders def to report to jail by 5 pm today or an arrest warrant will be issued.
Letter from DA re: Copy of summons and complaint to defendant
